sen.e: Under shoen koryo sei (The System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in the early medieval period (from the late Heian period to the mid Kamakura period), "myo" (rice field lots in charge of a nominal holder) which was managed by a lord of public land qualified as Gunji (a local government official), Goji (a local government official under the ritsuryo system) or Hoji (an officer governing a public land), shokan (an officer governing shoen (manor)) often overlapped with a lord of public land, or some powerful myoshu (owner of rice fields) who was concurrently a peasant (they themselves rather held the status of peasant officially in the early age) was mixed in a mosaic-like manner.
